Package au.edu.anu.qgraph.queries

Interface Queryable

All Known Implementing Classes:
AndQuery, ClassQuery, ContainsSubstring, CountQuery, DateString, EdgeHasNode, EdgeListNodes, EdgeNodes, EdgeQuery, ElementLabel, ElementName, ElementProperty, EndsWith, EnumerationString, FileQuery, ForAllQuery, GraphIsTree, HasEdges, HasOnlyNodes, HasParent, IfThenQuery, InetAddressString, IntegerString, IsBoolean, IsClass, IsDate, IsDouble, IsEdge, IsEnumeration, IsFloat, IsInstanceOf, IsInteger, IsIntegerRange, IsLong, IsMultiplicity, IsNode, IsOneOf, IsQuery, IsString, IsStringList, IsUMLAssociation, IsUMLAttribute, IsUMLClass, IsUMLClassModel, LongString, NodeCharacteristics, NodeEdges, NodeListEdges, NotQuery, OrQuery, PatternString, PopQuery, QueryAdaptor, QueryList, RealString, ResetQuery, SelectQuery, SequenceQuery, SizeQuery, StartsWith, StringLength, TreeQuery, Value, XorQuery
public interface Queryable

The ancestor class for the Query system.

Usage:

All Queries work in the same way:

  • An implementation of Queryable, matching the particular condition to fulfill, is constructed with some parameters needed to perform the query;
  • Later on, a call to Query.satisfied() will check the condition and return true if the Query was satisfied;
  • Alternatively, a call to Query.check(Object) can be made, that will return an Exception if the query is not satisfied.

Queries in the base package apply to non-graph objects.

The submit(...) method parameter type is generic (Object), but for every particular Query a specific type is required (cf. the javadoc for each specific Query type).

Some queries compute a result, accessible through the result() method. The default return type is Object, but the actual return type has to be known (cf. the javadoc for each specific Query type). A typical use case is returning a filtered list when the input to submit(...) is a list of items.

Author:
Shayne Flint - 15/3/2012, refactored by Ian Davies - 23 Feb. 2021
